item.title: Remote-work and burnout: 10 ways to avoid it on your tech team
item.dc:creator: svcselenium
item.description: For manyÂ tech pros, remote work isÂ hell because all the traditional work/home boundariesÂ are blurred. And in this economic environment, everyone is
item.content:encoded:
For manyÂ tech pros, remote work isÂ hell because all the traditional work/home boundariesÂ are blurred. And in this economic environment, everyone is trying to avoid getting laid off. All the more reason, then, for wanting or needing to beÂ always available to the job.

One example: having a security operations center dashboard on your mobile phone, to be alerted to problems day or night. That sort of connectivity canÂ bringÂ work-related stress to a whole new level.

TechBeaconÂ talked toÂ tech pros and HR managers to see what best practices have emerged in thisÂ remote era.Â Here are 10 suggestionsÂ for avoiding burnout as a development, testing, security, or other IT professional.

1. AcceptÂ that burnout is a real problem

The first step is to understand that burnout is real, said Jeff Gallimore, co-founder andÂ chief technology and innovation officer at Excella, a technology consulting firm.

“WeÂ are at an increased risk of burnout, particularly in these times. Our individual ability to deal with things is not what it was a year ago because of all the other things we have to deal with now, such as healthcare concerns.”
â€”Jeff Gallimore

That’s reducing the capacity of individuals to handle the other stuff that they used to cope with on a normal day-to-day basis at work, he said.

To help, Gallimore said, managers can take “a more proactive stance on trying to root out where those risks are” in their teams. One way to deal with it:Â “[By] realizing that my team might need a little bit more connection time in meetings just to catch up with each other.”

Rather than launching right into the agenda and starting to talkÂ about business or the work of the day that needs to get done, managers should create spaceÂ forÂ chatter, to maintain theÂ rapport that people used to have in the office, he said.

2. Communicate and connect

The mental health of all employees is especially critical during this tumultuous time, and individuals are struggling to manage the sudden shift to all-remote work, the need toÂ handle family and schooling priorities, and theirÂ feelings of isolation, saidÂ Shani Brounshtein, vice president of HR at Atera, an Israeli company that provides a remote-monitoringÂ management platform.Â 

“Instant messaging platforms can simulate a water cooler-style conversation and office banter. By connecting with each other, it can help bring the teams closer together.”
â€”Shani Brounshtein

In the pre-pandemicÂ world,Â Srini Vadlamani, CTO of Cyral, which makes aÂ cloud-native security tool,Â preferred face-to-face communication, because it allowed forÂ better conversation. Talking to someone in person also helped him understand what was going on from the other person’s point of view. Now, with the pandemic driving remote work, heÂ encourages employees to use video during online meetings.

“We have this culture where we all turn on our videos, unless someone’s not feeling so well.”
â€”Srini Vadlamani

3.Â Deliver a well-being program

When employees are burned out, it’s generally becauseÂ they have been hyper-engagedÂ for long periods of time without taking care of their well-being or having the support from their companies to take care of themselves, saidÂ Laura Hamill, chief people officer at Limeade, an employee experience company.

“Sometimes burnout goes so far that in order to cope with the exhaustion, cynicism, and inefficacy, employees start to detach and disengage from their work. When this happens, it’s easy for the employee to lose sight of why they liked their job in the first place and how their work helps them findÂ more meaning and purpose in their life.”
â€”Laura Hamill

To prevent employee burnout, organizations should deliver a well-being program, according to Hamill.Â This can includeÂ providing recovery time between big IT rollouts, training managers to support well-being within their teams, building support systems among employees, addressing unreasonable deadlines and overwork (often associated with IT departments), and helpingÂ peopleÂ reconnect to their sense of purpose at work, she said.

4.Â Hold mindful meetings

Meetings have increased on average for developers since the start of the pandemic, according to an analysis based onÂ over 2,000 developers conducted by Uplevel, an engineering effectiveness platform.Â 

Developers are working longer hours, and the risk for developer burnout is high, in part because of the increase in overall time spent in meetings.

September tallied “one of the highest [meeting] increases we’ve seen, and we’ve also heard subjectively from our customers that everything has to be a meeting now,” said Ravs Kaur, chief technology officer at Uplevel.

One way organizations can deal with meeting burnout is to hold “mindful” team meetings. In other words,Â try starting meetings with a quick meditation orÂ allowing time for some chatÂ before diving into work, said Bryan Stallings, chief evangelist for Lucid, an online visual collaboration suite. One best practice he recommends: “Use visuals to create an interactive environment rather than an audience of zombies with a single person presenting.”

Bill Miller, CIO of NetAPP, a provider of cloud data services, said his company is very mindful when scheduling meetings, with the goals ofÂ makingÂ them shorter, but also as inclusiveÂ and as productive as possible.

Anything that can be read and digested ahead of aÂ meeting is sent via collaboration channels, he said.Â 

“[That gives]Â each person time to share their thoughts, which is something that didn’t always happen in a conference room, because the biggest voices with the most bravado often dominated the conversation. Now weâ€™re going more thoughtfully around the visual space asking every person for their opinion, and thatâ€™s bringing to light more ideas, more perspectives, and deepening the feeling of inclusion and belonging.”
â€”Bill Miller

5.Â Be aware of people’s time

Leaders have to ensure that they’re using their people efficiently, said Cyral’sÂ Vadlamani.

“Let’s say a team of five people are all watching all the Slack alerts for a security channel. Do they all need to be watching at all times during the day, during the week, during the weekend?”
â€”Srini Vadlamani

He suggests setting upÂ a rotationÂ and designatingÂ which team member will be responsible for monitoring the Slack alerts at a specific time.

Another suggestion is to urn off notifications during certain hours of the day, certain days of the week, and so on, he said.

“We basically encourage people to switch off, disconnect, when they don’t have anything to do. That way, at leastÂ for the time that they’re not engaged, they’re not being bombarded with all these sensory inputs.”
â€”Srini Vadlamani

6.Â Connect back with your purpose

One of the best approaches to combat burnout is for developers and IT pros to connect back with their purposeâ€”especially from the perspective of how their work impacts real human beings, according to Limeade’sÂ Hamill.

For example, remind yourself of the problems your customers face and how your technology is helping to solve them, she said. “How did your contribution help them? How did that feel? From an internal perspective, remind yourself of the projects that you worked on with others and how it felt to have a positive impact on your co-workers.”

Managers can help byÂ havingÂ “line-of-sight” discussions with their employees, describing to each employee how their specific work helps the team, department, and company be successful.Â “Sometimes, we might think that is obvious to our employees, but it isnâ€™t always,” she said.Â 

7.Â UseÂ the off switch

It’s important to remember that “always on” has a correspondingÂ off switchâ€”and it should be used, said Derek Weeks, vice president ofÂ Sonatype, a provider of DevSecOps-native tools.

He advocates having a set schedule for the day, a time to both start and stop. “[You] have to be steadfast. When it says, ‘Stop,’ it means stop. It doesn’t mean bring your phone to dinner and check what’s happening on Slack.”

Before the pandemic, when employees used to leave the office, they weren’t usuallyÂ responding to work issues when they got home in the evening. Rather, they were spending time with their kids, their partners, and their pets, Weeks said.

He said that although he works on Sundays and may send messages to his team on Sunday mornings, he doesn’t expect responsesÂ that day.Â 

“I let my team know that it is totally okay to wait until Monday to answer it. If it was so time-critical, I’d call them.”
â€”Derek Weeks

One of the keys to using the on/off switch when working remotely is to develop a physical action to support the shut-off valve, said Mika Liss, COO of NeuroLeadership Institute, a consulting company that aims to help organizations apply neuroscience to work.

For instance, if you decide to stop working at 5 p.m. every day, you have to take action to enforce that.

“Physically shut off your laptop you put it in a drawer. And since all tech people are online, you can have your teammates say something like, ‘Shutting down in five, four, three’â€”or you can put a reminder in your calendar.”
â€”Mika Liss

8.Â Offer flexible schedules

NetApp is giving its employees far more flexibility in terms of work hours and schedules now that everyone is working from home, Miller said.

“We understand that some families have young children at home to address, while other employees may care for elderly family members,” he said. “We need to be very sensitive to the unique needs of families to succeed both in business and in life, thus removing inherent stress and eventual burnout.”

Working from home has introduced the need for different perspectives on balance, Miller said.

“We deeply believe a healthy work-life balance and an inherent sense of accomplishment and job satisfaction will result in the best employees for the long term.”
â€”Bill Miller

9.Â Learn to collaborate remotely

Before the pandemic, remote workers could physically go into the office to get some help with a problem, said Hyoun Park, CEO and principal analyst at Amalgam Insights.

“You used some human interaction to figure out how to work with other people and get some things done, synchronously. Now, a lot of us have to get the same amount of communication and collaboration done [remotely], and we have to use the technical tools that we have.”
â€”Hyoun Park

The hardest part is understanding how to collaborate with other team members, especially when they’re nontechnical or business peopleâ€”for instance,Â the people who care about security and applications and development but who are in sales or marketing or other areas where they don’t deal with code, Park said.

Although remote access to systems and tools has been around for decades,Â without in-person human interaction, something gets lost in translation.

The majority of person-to-personÂ communicationÂ is nonverbal. “And a lot of that nuance gets lost because there’s just a little bit of a delay when we’re speaking to each other remotelyâ€”there’s less spatial detail that you can get from a two-inch box in a Zoom” meeting, Park said.

10.Â Reclaim your commute time

Justin Rodenbostel, vice president ofÂ solution delivery at SPR, which specializes in custom software development, said he used to have a 60-to-90-minute commute, and for a while he found himself logging on at the time that heÂ would have left for work, which lead toÂ really long days.

“We’re now working during the time that we spent commuting,” he said. People have to reclaim their commute times to preserve a normal workday, he added.

“This allows a time for the mental transition, which normally happens during your commute, to kind of warm your brain up for the day or wind it down at the end of the day so that you can switch from a family member to a team member and back to a family member.”
â€”Justin Rodenbostel

The new normal

This new landscape has alreadyÂ lasted much longer than most anticipatedâ€”and it will likely continue for some time.

Many developers and IT pros will ultimately workÂ remotely full time and may never return to the office. These tips will can help you avoid burnout and be more productive in this environment.

Keep learning
